awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Modeling Silane Spreading and Deposition for Liquid Lithography
awd_abstract_narration:
Liquid lithography is a promising, versatile, and accessible method for generating three-dimensional (3D) microstructures using standard lithography instrumentation. Extending and simplifying the fabrication process of 3D microstructures will advance a wide variety of technologies such as organ-on-a-chip devices, tissue engineering, microfluidics, optics and microelectronics. This team will develop a liquid lithography process that can be used for a variety of important applications.

This project will develop a predictive mathematical model for the diffusion and deposition of silane in a rectangular chamber geometry. Furthermore,by modifying the geometry of the external chamber surrounding the substrate, the passive diffusion process of the silane can be further tuned, allowing for greatly enhanced control of the spatial distribution of the substrate?s surface properties. The investigators will develop, analyze, and benchmark an accessible mathematical model for a critical stage of the process. They will recruit and directly supervise students with particular attention to students from underrepresented backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Liquid lithography represents a robust technique for fabricating three-dimensional (3D) microstructures on a two-dimensional template. Silanization of a surface is often a key step in the liquid lithography process and is used to alter the surface energy of the substrate and, consequently, the shape of the 3D microfeatures produced. In this project, we have developed a mathematical model for a passive technique that allows for the generation of silane gradients along the length of a substrate. The technique relies on a secondary diffusion chamber with a single opening, leading to a directional introduction of silane to the substrate via passive diffusion. The secondary chamber geometry influences the deposited gradient, which is shown to be well captured by Monte Carlo simulations that incorporate the passive diffusion and grafting processes.


Intellectual Merit: In this award, we have developed and experimentally validated a new mathematical model for passive geometrical control of the silanization process.  The work has drawn expertise from a variety of fields, including biomedical engineering, chemistry, material science, physics, and mathematics. Through our modeling efforts and collaborations with experimentalists, we have identified the physical mechanisms underlying the observed silane gradient and developed a validated, predictive model for the process.  While a large number of physical effects are at play in the application, we discovered that an effective 2D model of the secondary chamber that captures the passive diffusion and grafting behavior of individual molecules was sufficient to rationalize the experimental data.  The model was also designed to be easy to implement and run, such that it be used as a design tool to guide and inform future engineering applications.  The work has advanced general knowledge on the coupling of diffusive transport and surface treatment processes.


Broader Impacts: This award has fostered the collaboration of faculty, postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students across disciplines, including applied mathematics, mechanical engineering, applied physical sciences, and biomedical engineering. Thanks to this award, the Harris Lab at Brown University has hosted an outreach day during each edition of the Girls Get Math program hosted at the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM) that included a hands-on introduction to microfluidics. A learning module for high-school aged students was developed by a team of undergraduate students advised by PI Bernardi at Worcester Polytechnic Institute. This curriculum focuses on mathematical modeling of engineering applications and has already been used at the Girls Talk Math camps, currently hosted on three US University campuses. 


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Daniel M Harris

The secondary chamber geometry influences the deposited gradient, which is shown to be well captured by Monte Carlo simulations that incorporate the passive diffusion and grafting processes.
